conclusion: Identify whether A→B is an expansion or a compression.
On the P-V diagram A is to the upper left and B lies farther to the right at a lower pressure.

premise: On the P-V diagram A is to the upper left and B lies farther to the right at a lower pressure.
conclusion: Moving from A to B therefore means the volume increases while pressure falls, i.e. an expansion.
Recall what happens in an isothermal process for an ideal gas.
Temperature is constant, so ΔU = 0 (U depends only on T for an ideal gas).
From the first law, Q = W.
For an expansion, the work done by the gas W = ∫P dV is positive.

premise: For an expansion, the work done by the gas W = ∫P dV is positive. From the first law, Q = W.
conclusion: Because W is positive and Q = W under isothermal conditions, the heat Q must also be positive.

premise: Because W is positive and Q = W under isothermal conditions, the heat Q must also be positive.
conclusion: During the isothermal expansion A → B the ideal gas absorbs heat from its surroundings.
